awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The effect of social information on the perception of native- and nonnative-accented speech
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

When perceiving speech, listeners use non-speech information from their environment in addition to the speech itself. One visual cue that informs listeners' understanding of speech is their perception of a talker's ethnicity.  This doctoral dissertation improvement grant project examines the cognitive and linguistic mechanisms that drive this effect. In addition to informing scientific models of speech processing, the results of this project can shed light into the inequalities faced by speakers of English in the United States who belong to a minority race and/or speak English as a second language. This work can therefore serve as an important step toward addressing and reducing inequalities stemming from linguistic and racial biases.

This dissertation project investigates social priming – how social information affects perception of speech – for both native- and nonnative-accented speech. In a series of experiments, group-wide behavioral data and individual differences data are integrated to examine the time-course and specificity of social priming effects, their relationship with implicit racial associations, and their effect on perceptual adaptation to nonnative accents. To ensure appropriate power for examination of individual differences, a large number of participants are recruited through online data collection. Transcription tasks are used to assess listeners' ability to understand target sentences presented in background noise. For the investigation of perceptual adaptation to nonnative accent, curve-fitting mixed-effects models are used to estimate performance over the course of the experiment. Ultimately, results of this interdisciplinary work will provide foundational knowledge of how linguistic and racial biases impact how humans process speech.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary aim of this project was to investigate the effects of social information on the perception of both native- and nonnative-accented speech. 

 

Summary of Outcomes:

Listeners use more than just acoustic information when processing speech. Social information, such as a speaker’s perceived race or ethnicity, can also affect the processing of the speech signal, in some cases facilitating perception (referred to as “social priming”). For example, prior work had found that perception of Mandarin Chinese-accented English was better when viewing a picture of an East Asian face, as compared to a White face (McGowan, 2015).

 

In a series of experiments, we integrated group-wide behavioral data and individual differences data in an effort to replicate and expand upon this social priming effect. In our first experiment, we successfully replicated McGowan (2015) with novel stimuli and a larger sample size: Listeners had better recognition accuracy for Mandarin-accented English when viewing an East Asian face than a White face. Further, our results indicated that this social priming benefit was immediate; a difference in performance was detectable on Trial 1 of the task.

 

Although the results of this first experiment were promising, our subsequent investigations did not consistently reveal predicted social priming effects. Mirroring the design of McGowan (2015), we predicted that viewing a Middle Eastern face (compared to a White face) would facilitate perception of Arabic-accented English. However, we did not find any difference between the two priming conditions or between those conditions and a control. Additionally, this experiment did not successfully replicate our original result (i.e., there was no difference in performance on Mandarin-accented English for an East Asian versus a White face).

 

One of our sub-aims was to investigate uncommon combinations of minority race/ethnicity primes and nonnative accents. We hypothesized that social primes may have a high degree of specificity, such that specific races/ethnicities would be associated with specific accents. Thus, for Mandarin-accented English, viewing a Middle Eastern prime (i.e., a minority race/ethnicity prime that is uncommon for the accent) could incur a cost to listening performance compared to a control or an East Asian prime. Results were non-significant, but trends in the data indicated that the combination of an East Asian prime with Arabic accent resulted in lower accuracy compared to a White prime. However, the combination of a Middle Eastern prime with Mandarin accent did not (and may have actually benefitted listeners to some degree).

 

An additional sub-aim was to investigate whether individual differences in implicit racial/ethnic associations may predict social priming effects. Across three experiments, we examined perception of native-accented English as well as Mandarin-accented English. In large sample sizes (approximately 10x those of prior work; N = 350 per experiment), our results did not reveal social priming effects for native-accented speech and revealed only a marginal effect for nonnative-accented speech. Similarly, a relationship between priming effects and individual differences in implicit associations only emerged for  the nonnative accent. For subjects with more extreme implicit associations between White faces and the construct American and between East Asian faces and the construct Foreign, the social priming effect was marginally larger, as predicted.

 

Finally, we examined whether social primes may affect perceptual adaptation (“tuning”) to nonnative accent. In this final experiment, we predicted that subjects presented with East Asian primes during training would show better performance at training and at test (generalization to a novel speaker) compared to subjects presented with White primes. A control group who only completed the post-test session confirmed that subjects given a training session performed better, as expected. However, comparisons of the groups of subjects assigned to the East Asian and White primes during training revealed no differences.

 

Conclusions:

Across a range of experiments that examined perception of native- and nonnative-accented English speech presented in noise, we found inconsistent evidence that race and ethnicity information (presented via images of faces) affects speech perception. We conclude that the specificity of priming effects may depend on listeners’ level of familiarity with a given accent and/or racial/ethnic group, and that the mixed outcomes in the current work motivate further inquiries to determine whether social priming effects for nonnative-accented speech may be smaller and/or more context-dependent than previously hypothesized.

 

Broader Impacts:

Not all accents are viewed equally among language users. Speakers with nonnative accents often face prejudice and stigmatization that impacts their everyday lives. In addition to this, prior work indicated that listeners’ ability to understand a speaker may be affected by the speaker’s perceived race or ethnicity. Thus, in the present work we investigated a speaker’s perceived race or ethnicity affect the perception of both native- and nonnative-accented speech, and how these effects may interact with listeners’ internalized racial/ethnic biases. Our results indicate that the effects of perceived race/ethnicity may be context-dependent, or, at the very least, much smaller than indicated by prior work.
